revision.text:
{{For|ship classes with a similar name|C-class submarine (disambiguation){{!}}C-class submarine}} {|{{Infobox ship begin|sclass=2}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[File:Uss C-3 1909.jpg|300px|USS Tarpon (later C-3) in 1909]] |Ship caption=USS ''Tarpon'' (later ''C-3''), 1909 }} {{Infobox ship class overview |Name= |Builders=*[[General Dynamics Electric Boat|Electric Boat]] (design) *[[Fore River Shipyard]], [[Quincy, Massachusetts]] |Operators={{navy|USA}} |Class before=[[United States B-class submarine|B class]] |Class after=[[United States D-class submarine|D class]] |Subclasses= |Cost= |Built range=1906–1909 |In service range= |In commission range= 1908–1919 |Total ships building= |Total ships planned= |Total ships completed=5 |Total ships cancelled= |Total ships active= |Total ships laid up= |Total ships lost= |Total ships retired=5 |Total ships preserved= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship type=[[Submarine]] |Ship displacement=*{{convert|238|LT|t|abbr=on}} surfaced *{{convert|275|LT|t|abbr=on}} submerged |Ship length={{convert|105|ft|4|in|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|13|ft|11|in|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draft={{convert|10|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=*2 × Craig Shipbuilding Co. [[Petrol engine|gasoline engines]], {{convert|500|hp|abbr=on}} total<ref>[http://pigboats.com/subs/c-boats.html Pigboats.com C-boats page]</ref> *2 × [[Electro-Dynamic Company|Electro Dynamic]] [[electric motor]]s, {{convert|300|hp|abbr=on}} total *2 × 60-[[electrochemical cell|cell]] [[battery (electricity)|batteries]] *2 shafts<ref>Gardiner, p. 127</ref> |Ship speed=*{{convert|10.5|kn|lk=in}} surfaced *{{convert|9|kn}} submerged |Ship range={{convert|800|nmi}} (surfaced), {{convert|80|nmi}} (submerged) |Ship test depth={{convert|200|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship complement=15 (1 officer and 14 enlisted) |Ship armament=2 × {{convert|18|in|abbr=on|0}} bow [[torpedo tube]]s, (4 [[torpedo]]es) |Ship notes= }} |} The '''C-class submarines''' were five [[United States Navy]] submarines built by the [[Fore River Shipbuilding Company]] in [[Quincy, Massachusetts]], under a subcontract from the [[General Dynamics Electric Boat|Electric Boat Company]]. Built between 1906 and 1909, and in commission from 1908 to 1919, all five were subsequently sold for scrap in 1920. They were considerably larger than the preceding [[United States B-class submarine|B class]] at 275 tons submerged vs. 173 tons submerged, and were the first United States submarines with two-shaft propulsion, doubling the machinery of the B class.
==Design== These vessels included some features intended to increase underwater speed that were standard on United States submarines of this era, including a small sail and a rotating cap over the torpedo tube muzzles. For extended surface runs, the small sail was augmented with a temporary piping-and-canvas structure. Apparently, the "crash dive" concept had not yet been developed, as this would take considerable time to deploy and dismantle. This configuration remained standard through the [[United States L-class submarine|L class]], commissioned 1916-1917. The streamlined, rotating torpedo tube muzzle cap eliminated the drag that muzzle holes would otherwise cause. In the stowed position, the submarine appears to have no torpedo tubes, as the holes in the cap are covered by the bow stem. This feature remained standard through the [[United States K-class submarine|K class]], after which it was replaced with shutters that were standard through the 1950s.
==Service history== The C-class submarines served in the [[United States Fleet Forces Command|Atlantic Fleet]]. On 20 May 1913, the five C-class boats of the First Group, Submarine Flotilla, Atlantic Fleet, departed [[Norfolk, Virginia]] for [[Guantanamo Bay Naval Base|Guantanamo Bay]], Cuba. They exercised in Cuban waters, principally conducting torpedo exercises, until 7 December 1913. On that date the C-class boats, now of the redesignated First Division, escorted by four surface ships, sailed for [[Cristóbal, Colón|Cristóbal]] in the [[Panama Canal Zone]]. Five days later the ships completed the {{convert|700|mi|adj=on}} passage, at that time the longest cruise made by United States submarines under their own power. The submarines remained at the [[Coco Solo]] submarine base until they were decommissioned in 1919 and scrapped in 1920.<ref>{{cite DANFS | title = C-5 | url = http://www.history.navy.mil/research/histories/ship-histories/danfs/c/c-5.html| accessdate = 17 July 2010}}</ref>
==Ships== * {{USS|C-1|SS-9|3}} was launched on 4 October 1906 as ''Octopus'' and commissioned on 30 June 1908. Renamed ''C-1'' on 17 November 1911, the submarine was decommissioned on 4 August 1919, and sold for scrap on 13 April 1920.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.navsource.org/archives/08/08009.htm |title=Octopus / C-1 (SS-12) |work=navsource.org |accessdate=17 July 2010 }}</ref> * {{USS|C-2|SS-13|3}} was launched on 8 April 1909 as ''Stingray'' and commissioned on 23 November 1909. Renamed ''C-2'' on 17 November 1911, the submarine was decommissioned on 23 December 1919, and sold for scrap on 13 April 1920.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.navsource.org/archives/08/08013.htm |title=Stingray / C-2 (SS-13) |work=navsource.org |accessdate=17 July 2010 }}</ref> * {{USS|C-3|SS-14|3}} was launched on 8 April 1909 as ''Tarpon'' and commissioned on 23 November 1909. Renamed ''C-3'' on 17 November 1911, the submarine was decommissioned on 23 December 1919, and sold for scrap on 12 April 1920.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.navsource.org/archives/08/08014.htm |title=Tarpon / C-3 (SS-14) |work=navsource.org |accessdate=17 July 2010 }}</ref> * {{USS|C-4|SS-15|3}} was launched on 17 June 1909 as ''Bonita'' and commissioned on 23 November 1909. Renamed ''C-4'' on 17 November 1911, the submarine was decommissioned on 15 August 1919, and sold for scrap on 13 April 1920.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.navsource.org/archives/08/08015.htm |title=Bonita / C-4 (SS-15) |work=navsource.org |accessdate=17 July 2010 }}</ref> * {{USS|C-5|SS-16|3}} was launched on 16 June 1908 as ''Snapper'' and commissioned on 2 February 1910. Renamed ''C-5'' on 17 November 1911, the submarine was decommissioned on 23 December 1919, and sold for scrap on 13 April 1920.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.navsource.org/archives/08/08016.htm |title=Snapper / C-5 (SS-16) |work=navsource.org |accessdate=17 July 2010 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[U-5-class submarine (Austria-Hungary)]] — two built to same design

ISBN 0-85177-245-5. * Silverstone, Paul H., ''U.S. Warships of World War I'' (Ian Allan, 1970), ISBN 0-71100-095-6. *[http://www.navsource.org/archives/08/02idx.htm Navsource.org early submarines page] *[http://pigboats.com/subs/c-boats.html Pigboats.com C-boats page] *{{DANFS}}
